title: Overview of the EAM Framework
text: modular simulation engine built upon generalized evidence accumulation framework, within assume decision making characterized stochastic process evidence continuously collected time. accumulation unfolds infinitesimal increments dtdt, can approximated practice small time steps (example, 1,). moment--moment change accumulated evidence x(t)x(t) can expressed stochastic differential: dx(t)=v‚ãÖdt+s‚ãÖœÉ, dx(t) = v \cdot dt + s \cdot \sigma,  vv drift rate, dtdt time step, ss noise scaling parameter, œÉ\sigma diffusion noise term. process unfolds, accumulated evidence x(t)x(t) continues evolve reaches decision boundaries, point response triggered corresponding RT recorded. distance reaching boundary jointly determined two parameters: decision boundary (aa) starting point (zz). evidence accumulates, process continues x(t)+zx(t) + z first reaches either upper boundary aa falls lower boundary 0 (two-boundary EAMs). elapsed time start accumulation boundary crossing defines decision time; adding non-decision time t0t_{0} yields observable RT. modular simulation engine composes ten modules (see Figure 1): : number accumulators race compete toward decision boundary (e.g., one DDM LFM; multiple LBA, LCA, RDM) : hierarchical priors specifying mean, variance, regression coefficients core parameters evidence-accumulation process including drift rate, decision boundary, starting point/relative bias, non-decision time, leakage parameter, strength lateral inhibition, stability parameter. : specify formulas -subject -trial variability parameters, also allowing linking covariates subject- trial-level parameters. : linking accumulator‚Äôs parameter item indexes output positions generate accumulator-level parameter values drift rate decision boundary, also allowing linking covariates item-level parameters. : family diffusion noise (e.g., Gaussian vs.¬†L√©vy Œ±\alpha-stable vs.¬†deterministic ballistic). : configuration used model simulation, including model equations, number conditions, number trials per condition, implementation parameters. : criteria determining responses recorded (e.g., first boundary crossing , first nn releases within time limit). : discrete increment used approximate continuous-time evidence accumulation (default 1,). : algorithmic specification stochastic increments (e.g., additive vs.¬†multiplicative). : underlying architecture evidence accumulation (e.g., single-boundary vs.¬†double-boundary vs.¬†LCA accumulators). combining different modular components, engine can simulate responses RTs many representative EAMs (see section Models eam configurations representative EAM).

title: Models in eam
text: diffusion decision model (DDM) double-boundary single-accumulator EAM Gaussian noise. moment--moment change accumulated evidence x(t)x(t) expressed : dx(t)=v‚ãÖdt+œâ‚ãÖdWt, dx(t) = v \cdot dt + \omega \cdot dW_t, dWt‚àºN(0,dt), dW_t \sim N(0,\, dt),  diffusion noise term dWtdW_t time step drawn Gaussian distribution mean 0 variance dtdt. diffusion scaling parameter œâ\omega typically fixed 1. starting point zz DDM often expressed proportion decision boundary aa: z=œÅ‚ãÖ,œÅ‚àà[0,1], z = \rho \cdot , \qquad \rho \[0,\, 1],  œÅ\rho denotes relative bias toward upper boundary aa. larger œÅ\rho places starting point closer upper boundary, making easier faster process reach , increasing probability correct response. free parameters model thus include drift rate vv, decision boundary aa, starting point zz (relative bias œÅ\rho), non-decision time t0t_0. Beyond core parameters, DDM also incorporates three sources -trial variability: variability drift rate (svs_v), starting point (szs_z), non-decision time (st0s_{t0}). components optional, yet including enables model better capture empirical RT distributions, explain ‚Äúfast errors‚Äù, separate within-trial noise -trial variability.
code: # Set the number of accumulators in the model n_items <-1  prior_params <- tibble(   n_items = n_items )  # Specify the prior distributions for free parameters prior_formulas <- list(   # Decision boundary   A_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0.5, 3),   # Drift rate   V_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0.5, 3),   S_V ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0, 1),   # Non-decision time   ndt_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0, 1),   S_ndt ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0, 1),   # Relative starting point   Z_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-0.5, 0.5),   S_Z ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0, 0.3) )  # Specify the between-trial components (optional) between_trial_formulas <- list(   # Between trial variability in drift rate   V_var ~ distributional::dist_normal(0, S_V),   # Between trial variability in non-decision time   ndt_var ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-S_ndt, S_ndt),   # Between trial variability in starting point   Z_var ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-S_Z, S_Z) )  # Specify the item-level parameters item_formulas <- list(   # Relative starting point   Z ~ Z_0 + Z_var,   # Decision boundary   A_upper ~ A_0, # upper    A_lower ~ -A_0, # lower   # Drift rate   V ~ V_0 + V_var,   # Non-decision time   ndt ~ ndt_0 + ndt_var )  # Specify the diffusion noise noise_factory <- function(context) {   function(n, dt) {     rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(dt))   } }  sim_config <- new_simulation_config(   # Pass the model information   prior_formulas = prior_formulas,   between_trial_formulas = between_trial_formulas,   item_formulas = item_formulas,   # Specify the simulation conditions and number of trials   n_conditions_per_chunk = NULL, # NULL = automatic chunking   n_conditions = 1000,   n_trials_per_condition = 100,   # Specify the number of accumulators and the number of recorded accumulators   n_items = n_items,   max_reached = n_items,   # Specify the total elapsed time and time step   max_t = 10,   dt = 0.001,   # Specify the noise structure   noise_mechanism = "add",   noise_factory = noise_factory,   # Specify the model type   model = "ddm-2b",   # Specify the parallel computing settings   parallel = FALSE,   n_cores = NULL, # Will use default: detectCores() - 1   rand_seed = NULL # Will use default random seed )  # Output temporary path setup temp_output_path <- tempfile("eam_demo_output")  sim_output <- run_simulation(   config = sim_config,   output_dir = temp_output_path )  # Define the summary procedure summary_pipe <-   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx"),     acc = sum(choice == 1) / sum(!is.na(choice)),   ) +   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx", "choice"),     rt_quantiles = quantile(rt, probs = c(0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7 ,0.9))   )  # Calculate simulated summary statistics simulation_sumstat <- map_by_condition(   sim_output,   .progress = TRUE,   .parallel = FALSE,   function(cond_df) summary_pipe(cond_df) )

1   rand_seed = NULL # Will use default random seed )  # Output temporary path setup temp_output_path <- tempfile("eam_demo_output_1")  sim_output <- run_simulation(   config = sim_config,   output_dir = temp_output_path ) # Define the summary procedure summary_pipe <-   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx"),     acc = sum(item_idx == 1) / sum(!is.na(item_idx)),   ) +   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx", "item_idx"),     rt_quantiles = quantile(rt, probs = c(0.005, 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7 ,0.9, 0.995))   )  # Calculate simulated summary statistics simulation_sumstat <- map_by_condition(   sim_output,   .progress = TRUE,   .parallel = FALSE,   function(cond_df) summary_pipe(cond_df) )

Second, trial, drift rate accumulator drawn Gaussian distribution mean ViV_i variance œÑ\tau, representing variability quality evidence: vi‚àºN(Vi,œÑ). v_i \sim N(V_i,\ \tau). model identifiability, œÑ\tau typically fixed constant, constraints imposed mean drift rates (e.g., V1+V2=1V_1 + V_2 = 1). free parameters model thus include mean drift rate accumulator ViV_i, decision boundary aa, upper bound starting point ZZ, non-decision time t0t_0. design gives LBA greater flexibility capturing error RT distributions allows straightforward extension tasks two options simply adding accumulators.

1   rand_seed = NULL # Will use default random seed )  # Output temporary path setup temp_output_path <- tempfile("eam_demo_output_1")  sim_output <- run_simulation(   config = sim_config,   output_dir = temp_output_path )  # Define the summary procedure summary_pipe <-   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx"),     acc = sum(item_idx == 1) / sum(!is.na(item_idx)),   ) +   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx", "item_idx"),     rt_quantiles = quantile(rt, probs = c(0.005, 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7 ,0.9, 0.995))   )  # Calculate simulated summary statistics simulation_sumstat <- map_by_condition(   sim_output,   .progress = TRUE,   .parallel = FALSE,   function(cond_df) summary_pipe(cond_df) )

Between trial variability in drift rate   V_var ~ distributional::dist_normal(0, S_V),   # Between trial variability in non-decision time   ndt_var ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-S_ndt, S_ndt),   # Between trial variability in starting point   Z_var ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-S_Z, S_Z) )  # Specify the item-level parameters item_formulas <- list(   # Relative starting point   Z ~ Z_0 + Z_var,   # Decision boundary   A_upper ~ A_0, # upper    A_lower ~ -A_0, # lower   # Drift rate   V ~ V_0 + V_var,   # Non-decision time   ndt ~ ndt_0 + ndt_var )  # Specify the diffusion noise noise_factory <- function(context) {     alpha <- context$alpha     function(n, dt) sqrt(dt)*rstable(n, alpha = alpha, beta = 0, gamma = 1/sqrt(2), delta = 0) }  sim_config <- new_simulation_config(   # Pass the model information   prior_formulas = prior_formulas,   between_trial_formulas = between_trial_formulas,   item_formulas = item_formulas,   # Specify the simulation conditions and number of trials   n_conditions_per_chunk = NULL, # NULL = automatic chunking   n_conditions = 1000,   n_trials_per_condition = 100,   # Specify the number of accumulators and the number of recorded accumulators   n_items = n_items,   max_reached = n_items,   # Specify the total elapsed time and time step   max_t = 10,   dt = 0.001,   # Specify the noise structure   noise_mechanism = "add",   noise_factory = noise_factory,   # Specify the model type   model = "ddm-2b",   # Specify the parallel computing settings   parallel = FALSE,   n_cores = NULL, # Will use default: detectCores() - 1   rand_seed = NULL # Will use default random seed )  # Output temporary path setup temp_output_path <- tempfile("eam_demo_output")  sim_output <- run_simulation(   config = sim_config,   output_dir = temp_output_path )  # Define the summary procedure summary_pipe <-   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx"),     acc = sum(choice == 1) / sum(!is.na(choice)),   ) +   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx", "choice"),     rt_quantiles = quantile(rt, probs = c(0.005, 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7 ,0.9, 0.995))   )  # Calculate simulated summary statistics simulation_sumstat <- map_by_condition(   sim_output,   .progress = TRUE,   .parallel = FALSE,   function(cond_df) summary_pipe(cond_df) )

title: Models in eam
text: simulate multi-response EAM, introduced two additional components: position-dependent decision boundary function item-dependent drift rate function. First, decision boundary modeled linear increasing function output position oo: (o)=a0+a1‚ãÖo, (o) = a_{0} + a_{1}\cdot o,  a0a_{0} represents decision boundary first-retrieved item a1>0a_{1} > 0 captures rate boundary increases across retrieval positions. recall episode progresses, criterion terminating evidence accumulation becomes stringent. increase may arise increased caution memory retrieval. Importantly, boundary linked output position rather item index, items lower drift rates may reach lower boundary chance. Second, drift rates specified linear decreasing function item index ii: v()=v0+v1‚ãÖ, v() = v_{0} + v_{1}\cdot , v0v_{0} represents drift rate first item v1<0v_{1} < 0 reflects decline evidence strength across positions. intended capture reduction available memory cues retrieval strength later items, pattern commonly observed free recall tasks. following example use DDM template extend multi-response version:
code: # Set the number of accumulators in the model n_items <-3  # Specify the prior distributions for free parameters prior_formulas <- list(   n_items ~ 3,   # Decision boundary   A_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0.5, 3),   A_1 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0, 1),   # Drift rate   V_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0.5, 3),   V_1 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0, 0.3),   S_V ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0, 1),   # Non-decision time   ndt_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0, 1),   S_ndt ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0, 1),   # Relative starting point   Z_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-0.5, 0.5),   S_Z ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0, 0.3) )  # Specify the between-trial components (optional) between_trial_formulas <- list(   # Between trial variability in drift rate   V_var ~ distributional::dist_normal(0, S_V),   # Between trial variability in non-decision time   ndt_var ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-S_ndt, S_ndt),   # Between trial variability in starting point   Z_var ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-S_Z, S_Z) )  # Specify the item-level parameters item_formulas <- list(   # Relative starting point   Z ~ Z_0 + Z_var,   # Decision boundary   A_upper ~ (A_0 + seq(1, n_items) * A_1), # upper    A_lower ~ -(A_0 + seq(1, n_items) * A_1), # lower   # Drift rate   V ~ pmax(V_0 - seq(1, n_items) * V_1 + V_var, 1e-5),   # Non-decision time   ndt ~ ndt_0 + ndt_var )  # Specify the diffusion noise noise_factory <- function(context) {   function(n, dt) {     rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(dt))   } }  sim_config <- new_simulation_config(   # Pass the model information   prior_formulas = prior_formulas,   between_trial_formulas = between_trial_formulas,   item_formulas = item_formulas,   # Specify the simulation conditions and number of trials   n_conditions_per_chunk = NULL, # NULL = automatic chunking   n_conditions = 1000,   n_trials_per_condition = 100,   # Specify the number of accumulators and the number of recorded accumulators   n_items = n_items,   max_reached = n_items,   # Specify the total elapsed time and time step   max_t = 10,   dt = 0.001,   # Specify the noise structure   noise_mechanism = "add",   noise_factory = noise_factory,   # Specify the model type   model = "ddm-2b",   # Specify the parallel computing settings   parallel = FALSE,   n_cores = NULL, # Will use default: detectCores() - 1   rand_seed = NULL # Will use default random seed )  # Output temporary path setup temp_output_path <- tempfile("eam_demo_output")  sim_output <- run_simulation(   config = sim_config,   output_dir = temp_output_path )  # Define the summary procedure summary_pipe <-   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx","rank_idx"),     acc = sum(choice == 1) / sum(!is.na(choice)),   ) +   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx", "rank_idx","choice"),     rt_quantiles = quantile(rt, probs = c(0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7 ,0.9))   )  # Calculate simulated summary statistics simulation_sumstat <- map_by_condition(   sim_output,   .progress = TRUE,   .parallel = FALSE,   function(cond_df) summary_pipe(cond_df) )

title: Models in eam
text: two general strategies incorporating covariates models. first approach, model parameters allowed vary systematically function group trial-level covariates. Specifically, parameters generated according Œ∏i=Œ∏0+Œ∏covXi, \theta_i = \theta_0 + \theta_{\mathrm{cov}}\, X_i, Œ∏\theta denotes model parameters (e.g., drift rate, decision boundary, non-decision time), XiX_i covariate value trial ii, Œ∏0\theta_0 baseline (intercept) parameter, Œ∏cov\theta_{\mathrm{cov}} quantifies effect covariate. formulation flexible accommodates continuous discrete covariates. using simulation-based inference, choice summary statistics must reflect structure covariate. continuous covariates, summary statistics include estimated regression intercept slope capturing relationship response times (RTs) covariate. discrete covariates, summary statistics typically consist RT quantiles computed separately covariate level, together accuracy measures double-boundary EAMs. second approach, covariates trial-level neural signals injected directly accumulation process modulating model parameters. Specifically, package allows users link trial-level neural measurements EAM parameters latent-variable formulation. scaling parameter ss introduced map neural signal onto appropriate parameter scale, variance term œÑ2\tau^{2} captures discrepancy observed neural signal latent parameter value. formulation enables joint modeling neural behavioral data, allows formal tests whether incorporating neural information leads improved model performance. Formally, trial-level neural signal PiP_i (e.g., EEG fMRI measurements) linked corresponding parameter Œ∏i\theta_i via Œ∏i‚àºùí©(s‚ãÖPi,œÑ2). \theta_i \sim \mathcal{N}\bigl(s \cdot P_i,\, \tau^{2}\bigr). Reference: Ratcliff, R. (1978). theory memory retrieval. Psychological Review, 85 (2), 59‚Äì108. https://doi.org/10.1037/0033-295X.85.2.59 Usher, M., & McClelland, J. L. (2001). time course perceptual choice: leaky, competing accumulator model. Psychological Review, 108 (3), 550‚Äì592. https://doi.org/10.1037/0033-295X.108.3.550 Brown, S. D., & Heathcote, . (2008). simplest complete model choice response time: Linear ballistic accumulation. Cognitive Psychology, 57 (3), 153‚Äì178. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cogpsych.2007.12.002 Tillman, G., Van Zandt, T., & Logan, G. D. (2020). Sequential sampling models without random -trial variability: racing diffusion model speeded decision making. Psychonomic Bulletin & Review, 27 (5), 911‚Äì936. https://doi.org/10.3758/s13423-020-01719-6 Wieschen, E. M., Voss, ., & Radev, S. T. (2020). Jumping conclusion? L√©vy flight model decision making. Quantitative Methods Psychology, 16 (2), 120‚Äì132. https://doi.org/10.20982/tqmp.16.2.p120
code: # Set the number of accumulators in the model n_items <- 1  # Set the covariate cov1 <- rbinom(100,1,0.5)  # Specify the prior distributions for free parameters prior_formulas <- list(   n_items ~ 1,   # Decision boundary   A_beta_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0.5, 3),   A_beta_1 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-1, 1),   # Drift rate   V_beta_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0.5, 3),   V_beta_1 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-1, 1),   # Non-decision time   ndt_beta_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0, 1),   ndt_beta_1 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-1, 1),   # Relative starting point   Z_beta_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-0.5, 0.5),   Z_beta_1 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-0.5, 0.5) )  # Specify the between-trial components (optional) between_trial_formulas <- list(   # Covariate   rlang::expr(cov1 ~ !!cov1) )  # Specify the item-level parameters item_formulas <- list(   # Relative starting point   Z ~ Z_beta_0 + cov1 * Z_beta_1,   # Decision boundary   A_upper ~ (A_beta_0 + cov1 * A_beta_1), # upper    A_lower ~ -(A_beta_0  + cov1 * A_beta_1), # lower   # Drift rate   V ~ pmax(V_beta_0 + cov1 * V_beta_1, 1e-5),   # Non-decision time   ndt ~ pmax(ndt_beta_0 + cov1 * ndt_beta_1, 1e-5) )  # Specify the diffusion noise noise_factory <- function(context) {   function(n, dt) {     rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(dt))   } }  sim_config <- new_simulation_config(   # Pass the model information   prior_formulas = prior_formulas,   between_trial_formulas = between_trial_formulas,   item_formulas = item_formulas,   # Specify the simulation conditions and number of trials   n_conditions_per_chunk = NULL, # NULL = automatic chunking   n_conditions = 1000,   n_trials_per_condition = 100,   # Specify the number of accumulators and the number of recorded accumulators   n_items = n_items,   max_reached = n_items,   # Specify the total elapsed time and time step   max_t = 10,   dt = 0.001,   # Specify the noise structure   noise_mechanism = "add",   noise_factory = noise_factory,   # Specify the model type   model = "ddm-2b",   # Specify the parallel computing settings   parallel = FALSE,   n_cores = NULL, # Will use default: detectCores() - 1   rand_seed = NULL # Will use default random seed )  # Output temporary path setup temp_output_path <- tempfile("eam_demo_output")  sim_output <- run_simulation(   config = sim_config,   output_dir = temp_output_path )  # Define the summary procedure summary_pipe <-   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx","rank_idx","cov1"),     acc = sum(choice == 1) / sum(!is.na(choice)),   ) +   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx", "rank_idx","choice","cov1"),     rt_quantiles = quantile(rt, probs = c(0.005, 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7 ,0.9, 0.995))   )  # Calculate simulated summary statistics simulation_sumstat <- map_by_condition(   sim_output,   .progress = TRUE,   .parallel = FALSE,   function(cond_df) summary_pipe(cond_df) ) # Set the number of accumulators in the model n_items <- 1  # Set the covariate cov1 <- rnorm(100,1,0.5)  # Specify the prior distributions for free parameters prior_formulas <- list(   n_items ~ 1,   # Decision boundary   A_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0.5, 3),   # Drift rate   V_coef ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0.5, 3),   V_sigma ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0, 1),   # Non-decision time   ndt_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0, 1),   # Relative starting point   Z_0 ~ distributional::dist_uniform(-0.5, 0.5) )  # Specify the between-trial components (optional) between_trial_formulas <- list(   # Covariate   rlang::expr(cov1 ~ !!cov1),   V_latent ~ V_coef * stats::rnorm(1,mean=cov1,sd=V_sigma) )  # Specify the item-level parameters item_formulas <- list(   # Relative starting point   Z ~ Z_0,   # Decision boundary   A_upper ~ (A_0), # upper    A_lower ~ -(A_0), # lower   # Drift rate   V ~ pmax(V_latent, 1e-5),   # Non-decision time   ndt ~ ndt_0 )  # Specify the diffusion noise noise_factory <- function(context) {   function(n, dt) {     rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(dt))   } }  sim_config <- new_simulation_config(   # Pass the model information   prior_formulas = prior_formulas,   between_trial_formulas = between_trial_formulas,   item_formulas = item_formulas,   # Specify the simulation conditions and number of trials   n_conditions_per_chunk = NULL, # NULL = automatic chunking   n_conditions = 1000,   n_trials_per_condition = 100,   # Specify the number of accumulators and the number of recorded accumulators   n_items = n_items,   max_reached = n_items,   # Specify the total elapsed time and time step   max_t = 10,   dt = 0.001,   # Specify the noise structure   noise_mechanism = "add",   noise_factory = noise_factory,   # Specify the model type   model = "ddm-2b",   # Specify the parallel computing settings   parallel = FALSE,   n_cores = NULL, # Will use default: detectCores() - 1   rand_seed = NULL # Will use default random seed )  # Output temporary path setup temp_output_path <- tempfile("eam_demo_output")  sim_output <- run_simulation(   config = sim_config,   output_dir = temp_output_path )  # Define the summary procedure summary_pipe <-   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx"),     acc = sum(choice == 1) / sum(!is.na(choice)),     lm_coef = lm(rt ~ cov1)$coefficients   ) +   summarise_by(     .by = c("condition_idx", "choice"),     rt_quantiles = quantile(rt, probs = c(0.005, 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9, 0.995))   )  # code: @Manual{,   title = {eam: Evidence Accumulation Models},   author = {Guangyu Zhu and Guang Yang},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 1.0.1},   url = {https://y-guang.github.io/eam}, }

title: Evidence Accumulation Models
text: eam simulation-based evidence accumulation models analyzing responses reaction times single- multi-response tasks. package includes simulation engines five representative models: Diffusion Decision Model (DDM), Leaky Competing Accumulator (LCA), Linear Ballistic Accumulator (LBA), Racing Diffusion Model (RDM), L√©vy Flight Model (LFM), extends frameworks multi-response settings. package supports user-defined functions item-level parameterization incorporation covariates, enabling flexible customization development new model variants based existing architectures. Inference performed using simulation-based methods, including Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC) Amortized Bayesian Inference (ABI), allow parameter estimation without requiring tractable likelihood functions. addition core inference tools, package provides modules parameter recovery, posterior predictive checks, model comparison. Overall, facilitates study wide range cognitive processes tasks involving perceptual decision making, memory retrieval, value-based decision making.

title: Evidence Accumulation Models
text: Documentation (users): User-facing documentation tutorials, usage examples, model overviews. Development repository (developers): GitHub repository source code, development discussions, issue/PR tracking. main branch reflects development version, tags used stable releases. CRAN page: official CRAN page eam package.

title: Evidence Accumulation Models
text: Pure C++ core fast vectorization-friendly algorithms designed. 100x speedup compared naive python implementations. Memory-efficient computation, enabling 10 million trials standard desktop machine. Parallel execution near-linear speed-across multiple CPU cores. Flexible architecture: composable api, defines several formulas, can easily customize models. modern R apiÔºöBuilt around modern R conventions, provides declarative, tidy-style interface. Unified data pipeline: provides consistent set data manipulation summarization utilities seamless simulation, evaluation, visualization.

title: ABC model comparison wrapper ‚Äî abc_postpr
code: # Load pre-computed ABC input for model comparison # This example compares the same model to itself for demonstration rdm_minimal_example <- system.file("extdata", "rdm_minimal", package = "eam") abc_input <- readRDS(file.path(rdm_minimal_example, "abc", "abc_input.rds"))  # Compare two models using their summary statistics # In practice, create different abc_input objects for different models: # abc_input_1 <- build_abc_input(..., simulation_summary = sim_summary_1, ...) # abc_input_2 <- build_abc_input(..., simulation_summary = sim_summary_2, ...) postpr_result <- abc_postpr(   sumstats = list(model1 = abc_input$sumstat, model2 = abc_input$sumstat),   target = abc_input$target,   tol = 0.5,   method = "rejection" )  # View model comparison results summary(postpr_result) #> Call:  #> abc::postpr(target = target, index = index, sumstat = sumstat,  #>     tol = 0.5, method = "rejection") #> Data: #>  postpr.out$values (500 posterior samples) #> Models a priori: #>  model1, model2 #> Models a posteriori: #>  model1, model2 #>  #> Proportion of accepted simulations (rejection): #> model1 model2  #>    0.5    0.5  #>  #> Bayes factors: #>        model1 model2 #> model1      1      1 #> model2      1      1 #>  #>

title: Build input for Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC) ‚Äî build_abc_input
text: function provides streamlined workflow preparing ABC inputs, requires components constructed using package's functions. Specifically, simulation_output must created run_simulation load_simulation_output, simulation_summary target_summary must generated using summarise_by. data originates external sources custom pipelines, manually construct ABC input list instead, ensuring proper matrix formatting column alignment expected abc::abc.

title: Build input for Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC) ‚Äî build_abc_input
text: simulation_summary target_summary must created using summarise_by. ensures consistent column naming data structure required ABC analysis. See summarise_by details generating properly formatted summaries, map_by_condition typical workflow examples. want flexibility summary statistic calculation, can manually construct ABC input list. necessary use function familiar abc package.

title: Build input for Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC) ‚Äî build_abc_input
code: # \donttest{ # Load the example dataset rdm_minimal_example <- system.file("extdata", "rdm_minimal", package = "eam") sim_output <- load_simulation_output(file.path(rdm_minimal_example, "simulation")) obs_df <- read.csv(file.path(rdm_minimal_example, "observation", "observation_data.csv"))  # Define summary statistics pipeline summary_pipe <- summarise_by(   .by = c("condition_idx"),   rt_mean = mean(rt) )  # Calculate summary statistics for simulation and observation sim_summary <- map_by_condition(   sim_output,   .progress = FALSE,   .parallel = FALSE,   function(cond_df) {     summary_pipe(cond_df)   } ) obs_summary <- summary_pipe(obs_df)  # Build ABC input abc_input <- build_abc_input(   simulation_output = sim_output,   simulation_summary = sim_summary,   target_summary = obs_summary,   param = c("V_beta_1", "V_beta_group") )  # Perform ABC parameter estimation using rejection method abc_rejection_model <- abc::abc(   target = abc_input$target,   param = abc_input$param,   sumstat = abc_input$sumstat,   tol = 0.5,   method = "rejection" ) # }

title: Create a new simulation configuration ‚Äî new_simulation_config
text: prior_params list data frame initial values prior prior_formulas list formulas defining prior distributions condition-level parameters between_trial_formulas list formulas defining -trial parameters item_formulas list formulas defining item-level parameters n_conditions_per_chunk Number conditions process per chunk (optional, typically need set. determine storage -memory size chunk, find memory issues, try reducing number) n_conditions Total number conditions simulate n_trials_per_condition Number trials per condition n_items Number items per trial max_reached Maximum number items can recalled (default: n_items) max_t Maximum simulation time dt Time step size (default: 0.001) noise_mechanism Noise mechanism ("add", "mult_evidence", "mult_t", default: "add") noise_factory Function creates noise functions. model Model name backend names (e.g., "ddm", "rdm", "lca") parallel Whether run parallel (default: FALSE) n_cores Number cores parallel processing (default: NULL, auto-detect) rand_seed Random seed parallel processing (default: NULL)

title: Create a new simulation configuration ‚Äî new_simulation_config
text: S3 object class eam_simulation_config containing validated   simulation parameters. object passed   run_simulation execute simulation.

title: Create a new simulation configuration ‚Äî new_simulation_config
text: function creates configuration object run simulation. actually execute simulation, must pass returned configuration object run_simulation. Supported Models: package supports three evidence accumulation models. appropriate backend automatically selected based model parameter parameters defined formulas. DDM (Drift Diffusion Model) Models evidence accumulation towards single upper threshold. Items     either reach threshold recalled, time . Required parameters (must appear prior_formulas,     between_trial_formulas, item_formulas): - Upper decision boundary/threshold V - Drift rate (evidence accumulation rate) Z - Starting point evidence ndt - Non-decision time Set model = "ddm" RDM (Racing Diffusion Model) Models multiple racing evidence accumulators, upper lower     thresholds binary decisions (correct/incorrect). Required parameters: A_upper - Upper decision boundary (correct response) A_lower - Lower decision boundary (incorrect response) V - Drift rate Z - Starting point evidence ndt - Non-decision time Set model = "rdm". Note: set model = "ddm"     define A_upper instead , model automatically     switch RDM. LCA (Leaky Competing Accumulator) Models competitive evidence accumulation leakage mutual     inhibition accumulators. Required parameters: - Decision threshold V - Input strength/drift rate Z - Starting point evidence ndt - Non-decision time beta - Self-excitation/leak parameter k - Lateral inhibition strength Set model = "lca" LFM (L√©vy Flight Model) Uses parameters DDM. See DDM . Set model = "lfm" LBA (Linear Ballistic Accumulator) Uses parameters RDM. See RDM . Set model = "lba" Note: required parameters must defined least across prior_params, prior_formulas, between_trial_formulas, item_formulas. Parameter Hierarchy Formula Evaluation: simulation uses hierarchical parameter system sequential formula evaluation, allowing later formulas reference earlier ones: prior_params - Initial constant values available formulas prior_formulas - Evaluated per condition, can reference         prior_params. Use condition-level parameters vary         across conditions. between_trial_formulas - Evaluated per trial within         condition. Can reference prior_params variables         prior_formulas. Use trial-level variability. item_formulas - Evaluated per item within trial.         Can reference previous parameters. Use item-specific parameters. Using Distributions: can use distributional package define random parameters. example: ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0.5, 2.0) - Uniform distribution V_condition ~ distributional::dist_normal(1.0, 0.2) - Normal distribution sigma ~ 0.5 - Constant value V ~ distributional::dist_normal(V_condition, sigma) - Reference earlier parameters formula evaluated sequentially, can build complex parameter dependencies. instance, might define base drift rate V prior_formulas, add trial-level noise between_trial_formulas, finally scale item position item_formulas.

title: Create a new simulation configuration ‚Äî new_simulation_config
code: # Define formulas for the simulation prior_formulas <- list(   V ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0.1, 1.0),   ndt ~ 0.3,   noise_coef ~ 1 )  between_trial_formulas <- list()  item_formulas <- list(   A_upper ~ 1,   A_lower ~ -1,   V ~ V )  # Define noise factory noise_factory <- function(context) {   noise_coef <- context$noise_coef   function(n, dt) {     noise_coef * rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(dt))   } }  # Create configuration config <- new_simulation_config(   prior_formulas = prior_formulas,   between_trial_formulas = between_trial_formulas,   item_formulas = item_formulas,   n_conditions = 10,   n_trials_per_condition = 10,   n_items = 5,   max_reached = 5,   max_t = 10,   dt = 0.01,   noise_mechanism = "add",   noise_factory = noise_factory,   model = "ddm",   parallel = FALSE )  # print the config config #> eam Simulation Configuration #> ================================= #> Model: ddm  #> Backend: ddm-2b  #> Conditions: 10  #> Trials per condition: 10  #> Items per trial: 5  #> Max reached: 5  #> Max time: 10  #> Time step: 0.01  #> Noise mechanism: add  #> Conditions per chunk: 10  #> Parallel: FALSE  #>  #> Formulas: #>   Prior formulas: 3  #>   Between-trial formulas: 0  #>   Item formulas: 3   # Run simulation sim_output <- run_simulation(config) #> Error in accumulate_evidence_ddm_2b(item_params$A_upper, item_params$A_lower,     item_params$V, Z, item_params$ndt, max_t, dt, max_reached,     noise_mechanism, noise_fun): could not find function "accumulate_evidence_ddm_2b" sim_output #> Error: object 'sim_output' not found

title: Run a simulation with specified configuration ‚Äî run_simulation
text: function uses --core approach handle potentially large simulation results. Instead returning data frame directly, persists data disk returns eam_simulation_output object contains metadata file system paths. access simulation data, use following methods returned object: open_dataset() - Returns Arrow Dataset containing   simulation results, e.g. sim_output$open_dataset() open_evaluated_conditions() - Returns Arrow Dataset   containing evaluated condition parameters, e.g.   sim_output$open_evaluated_conditions() methods return Arrow Dataset objects rather data frames, allowing efficient querying filtering loading data memory. convert data frame, use dplyr::collect() .data.frame(). Throughout package, eam_simulation_output object used standard parameter downstream analysis functions, rather passing Arrow objects data frames directly. multi-item backends, discrete time point, one item can reach threshold. precision detection depends dt parameter. design choice made performance considerations. almost experimental scenarios, negligible. users aware limitation, critical, try increase temporal resolution reducing dt. implementation details, refer backend source code (accumulate_evidence_* functions).

title: Run a simulation with specified configuration ‚Äî run_simulation
code: # Define formulas for the simulation prior_formulas <- list(   V ~ distributional::dist_uniform(0.1, 1.0),   ndt ~ 0.3,   noise_coef ~ 1 )  between_trial_formulas <- list()  item_formulas <- list(   A_upper ~ 1,   A_lower ~ -1,   V ~ V )  # Define noise factory noise_factory <- function(context) {   noise_coef <- context$noise_coef   function(n, dt) {     noise_coef * rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(dt))   } }  # Create configuration config <- new_simulation_config(   prior_formulas = prior_formulas,   between_trial_formulas = between_trial_formulas,   item_formulas = item_formulas,   n_conditions = 10,   n_trials_per_condition = 10,   n_items = 5,   max_reached = 5,   max_t = 10,   dt = 0.01,   noise_mechanism = "add",   noise_factory = noise_factory,   model = "ddm",   parallel = FALSE )  # Run simulation sim_output <- run_simulation(config) #> Error in accumulate_evidence_ddm_2b(item_params$A_upper, item_params$A_lower,     item_params$V, Z, item_params$ndt, max_t, dt, max_reached,     noise_mechanism, noise_fun): could not find function "accumulate_evidence_ddm_2b"  # Access results dataset <- sim_output$open_dataset() #> Error: object 'sim_output' not found dataset # an arrow dataset object #> Error: object 'dataset' not found  # if you want to load it into memory, you can use: df <- as.data.frame(dataset) #> Error: object 'dataset' not found head(df) #>                                                #> 1 function (x, df1, df2, ncp, log = FALSE)     #> 2 {                                            #> 3     if (missing(ncp))                        #> 4         .Call(C_df, x, df1, df2, log)        #> 5     else .Call(C_dnf, x, df1, df2, ncp, log) #> 6 }                                             # Access evaluated condition parameters cond_dataset <- sim_output$open_evaluated_conditions() #> Error: object 'sim_output' not found df_cond <- as.data.frame(cond_dataset) #> Error: object 'cond_dataset' not found head(df_cond) #> Error: object 'df_cond' not found

title: Summarise data by groups with optional pivoting ‚Äî summarise_by

title: Summarise data by groups with optional pivoting ‚Äî summarise_by
text: .data data frame summarise, NULL create reusable summary function ... Summary expressions using dplyr-style syntax. Named arguments become column names output (e.g., `mean_rt = mean(rt)`). .Character vector grouping column names. Default "condition_idx". .wider_by Character vector columns keep identifiers pivoting. Default "condition_idx". Must subset `.`. `.wider_by` differs `.`, extra columns `.` spread across column suffixes.

title: Summarise data by groups with optional pivoting ‚Äî summarise_by
text: - `.data` provided: data frame summarised results - `.data` NULL: function can applied data later

title: Summarise data by groups with optional pivoting ‚Äî summarise_by
text: can use `summarise_by()` two ways: 1. **Direct use**: Pass data directly get results immediately 2. **Build--apply**: Create reusable summary functions, combine `+`,    apply data later build--apply approach useful want compute different types summaries (e.g., RT statistics accuracy statistics) automatically join together.

title: Summarise data by groups with optional pivoting ‚Äî summarise_by
text: plan use build_abc_input ABC analysis, must use summarise_by() generate summary statistics (manually handle arrow output format). function typically works together map_by_condition process simulation results. See map_by_condition workflow examples.

title: Summarise data by groups with optional pivoting ‚Äî summarise_by
code: # Example 1: Direct use - pass data and get results immediately trial_data <- data.frame(   condition_idx = rep(1:2, each = 4),   item_idx = rep(1:2, 4),   rt = c(0.5, 0.6, 0.7, 0.8, 0.55, 0.65, 0.75, 0.85),   accuracy = c(1, 1, 0, 1, 1, 0, 1, 1) )  # Compute mean RT and accuracy by condition and item result <- summarise_by(   trial_data,   mean_rt = mean(rt),   mean_acc = mean(accuracy),   .by = c("condition_idx", "item_idx"),   .wider_by = "condition_idx" ) # Result has columns: condition_idx, mean_rt_item_idx_1, mean_rt_item_idx_2, etc. result #> # A tibble: 2 √ó 5 #>   condition_idx mean_rt_item_idx_1 mean_rt_item_idx_2 mean_acc_item_idx_1 #>           <int>              <dbl>              <dbl>               <dbl> #> 1             1               0.6                0.7                  0.5 #> 2             2               0.65               0.75                 1   #> # ‚Ñπ 1 more variable: mean_acc_item_idx_2 <dbl>  # Example 2: Build-then-apply - create reusable summary functions # Build separate summary functions for different statistics rt_summary_pipe <- summarise_by(   mean_rt = mean(rt),   sd_rt = stats::sd(rt),   .by = c("condition_idx", "item_idx"),   .wider_by = "condition_idx" )  acc_summary_pipe <- summarise_by(   mean_acc = mean(accuracy),   n_trials = length(accuracy),   .by = c("condition_idx", "item_idx"),   .wider_by = "condition_idx" )  # Combine with + and apply to data combined_summary_pipe <- rt_summary_pipe + acc_summary_pipe result <- combined_summary_pipe(trial_data) # Result has all summaries joined by condition_idx result #> # A tibble: 2 √ó 9 #>   condition_idx mean_rt_item_idx_1 mean_rt_item_idx_2 sd_rt_item_idx_1 #>           <int>              <dbl>              <dbl>            <dbl> #> 1             1               0.6                0.7             0.141 #> 2             2               0.65               0.75            0.141 #> # ‚Ñπ 5 more variables: sd_rt_item_idx_2 <dbl>, mean_acc_item_idx_1 <dbl>, #> #   mean_acc_item_idx_2 <dbl>, n_trials_item_idx_1 <int>, #> #   n_trials_item_idx_2 <int>

title: Summarise posterior parameter distributions ‚Äî summarise_posterior_parameters
code: # Load ABC output from saved file abc_file <- system.file(   "extdata", "rdm_minimal", "abc", "abc_rejection_model.rds",   package = "eam" ) abc_rejection_model <- readRDS(abc_file)  # Summarise posterior distributions summarise_posterior_parameters(abc_rejection_model) #>      parameter      mean    median ci_lower_0.025 ci_upper_0.975 #> 1     V_beta_1 0.2684096 0.2607152      0.1119190      0.4470107 #> 2 V_beta_group 0.1949098 0.1879120      0.1036883      0.2958763  # Custom confidence interval level summarise_posterior_parameters(abc_rejection_model, ci_level = 0.90) #>      parameter      mean    median ci_lower_0.050 ci_upper_0.950 #> 1     V_beta_1 0.2684096 0.2607152      0.1291406       0.422611 #> 2 V_beta_group 0.1949098 0.1879120      0.1070319       0.290407

title: Summarise resample medians ‚Äî summarise_resample_medians
code: # Load ABC input data from example simulation abc_input <- readRDS(   system.file("extdata", "rdm_minimal", "abc", "abc_input.rds", package = "eam") )  # Perform ABC resampling results <- abc_resample(   target = abc_input$target,   param = abc_input$param,   sumstat = abc_input$sumstat,   n_iterations = 100,   n_samples = 100,   tol = 0.5,   method = "rejection" )  # summarise the resample medians summary_stats <- summarise_resample_medians(results, ci_level = 0.95) print(summary_stats) #>      parameter      mean    median ci_lower_0.025 ci_upper_0.975 #> 1     V_beta_1 0.2603399 0.2603058      0.2307077      0.2915249 #> 2 V_beta_group 0.1893953 0.1885646      0.1678800      0.2107938
